questions.text: Structures passing between upper border of superior constrictor muscle and base of skull Include all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Tensor tympani
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:    
•    Tensor tympani, as the name indicates, is a muscle of the middle car. II enters the middle ear through canal for tensor tympani. Its tendon hooks round the processus cochleariformis, turns 90° laterally and gels attached 10 the neck of malleus. 
•    Structures which pass between base of skull and superior constrictor muscle are: (i) Levator (veli) palatini (ii) Tensor (veli) palatini 
•    (iii) Eustachian tube (iv) Ascending palatine artery (branch of facial artery) (v) Ascending pharyngeal artery (branch of exterior carotid)

choices.text: Ossicular fixation with intact tympanic membrane
Ossicular fixation with perforated tympanic membrane
Erosion of stapes footplate with perforated tympanic membrane

questions.text: A 20-year-old pregnant female presents with conductive hearing loss of 54db, not associated with tinnitus. Pure tone audiometry shows a notch at 2000 Hz. Which of the following is correct regarding the pathophysiology of the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ossicular fixation with intact tympanic membrane
Ref: Read the text below    
Sol:
•    The given clinical scenario of a young pregnant female with bilateral conducting hearing loss and notch at 2000Hz (Carhart’s notch) is suggestive of otosclerosis where there is an ossicular fixation with the intact tympanic membrane.
•    Otosclerosis is the disease of the bony labyrinth in which a normally dense endochondral layer of the bony otic capsule is replaced by irregularly laid spongy bone. It has a positive family history with an autosomal dominant trait. 
•    It is more commonly seen in fernales between 20-30 years of age and the hearing loss is aggravated during pregnancy and menopause. 
•    It may be associated with osteogenesis imperfecta and a viral infection like measles.

questions.text: A 6 year old child with the history of mouth breathing, high arched palate, failure to thrive and hearing loss . Which of the following will be best management plan for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion
Sol :  

•    This child is probably suffering from adenotonsillar hypertrophy which is causing recurrent respiratory tract infection and mouth breathing. 
•    Hypertrophied adenoids/tonsils might have led to Eustachian tube blockade with a resultant SOM which explains decreased hearing. 
•    So the treatment is Myringotomy with grommet insertion along with Adeno-tonsillectomy in the same sitting.
•    Myringoplasty is the surgical repair of TM and is done in CSOM.

questions.text: A patient presents to ENT OPD with pulsatile tinnitus,reddish mass behind tympanic membrane. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Glomus tumour
Sol :  

                          Glomus Tumors (Paragangliomas, Chemodectomas)
Glomus Tumor: slow growing, benign tumor although locally destructive (expansive, bone eroding) of the chemoreceptive cells (paraganglion cells, neural crest in origin) distributed along parasympathetic nerves in the base of skull, neck, and chest
• Most common benign tumor of the temporal bone of adults (rare in pediatrics)
Glomus Vagale: arise from paraganglia around the vagus nerve at the base of skull
• SSx: pulsatile tinnitus (most common symptom), hearing loss, cranial nerve palsies, aural discharge, otalgia, dizziness (invasion of the labyrinth), reddish middle ear mass, BROWN’S SIGN (BLANCHING OF THE TM WITH POSITIVE PRESSURE)
• Rx: surgical resection after preoperative embolization or primary
radiation therapy for nonoperable candidates, advanced tumors, or presence of residual disease

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was brought to OPD with a history of URTI. He also has features of mouth breathing, sleep apnoea and nasal obstruction. The mother has noticed that the child increases the volume while watching TV. What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion
Ref: Read the text below    
Sol:
•    The given clinical scenario of a child with mouth breathing. 
•    Sleep apnoea, nasal obstruction, and decreased hearing points towards the diagnosis of serous otitis media secondary to adenoid hypertrophy. Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion would be the most appropriate management.
•    Adenoid hypertrophy causes typical facies characterized by an elongated face with a dull expression, an open mouth, a hitched-up upper lip, prominent upper teeth causing crowding (malocclusion of teeth), a high arched hard palate (due to loss of tongue’s molding action on the palate), and a pinched-in nose due to disuse atrophy of the alae nasi.

questions.text: 6 yr old child bought by mom with history of loss of hearing in one ear since 2 months .Study the the given otoscopic finding and comment on the diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Serous otitis Media

Most cases of bullous myringitis occur in males between the ages of 2 to 8 years old, whereas AOM is most commonly seen in children less than two years of age

questions.text: A 30- year old woman with family history of hearing loss from her mother's side developed hearing problem dur¬ing pregnancy. Hearing loss is bilateral, slowly progres¬sive, Pure tone audiometry shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Otosclerosis
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:  
•    Otosclerosis is traditionally diagnosed by characteristic clinical findings, which include progressive conductive hearing loss, a normal tympanic membrane, and no evidence of middle ear inflammation. The cochlear promontory may have a faint pink tinge reflecting the vascularity of the lesion, referred to as the Schwartze sign.
•    Conductive hearing loss is usually secondary to impingement of abnormal bone on the stapes footplate. This involvement of the oval window forms the basis of the name fenestral otosclerosis.
•    The most common location of involvement of otosclerosis is the bone just anterior to the oval window at a small cleft known as the fissula ante fenestram.
•    The fissula is a thin fold of connective tissue extending through the endochondral layer, approximately between the oval window and the cochleariform process, where the tensor tympani tendon turns laterally toward the malleus.
•    As 2 kHz is the resonant frequency of the ossicular chain, the largest increase in bone conduction threshold (around 15 dB) occurs at this frequency – the resultant notch is called 
•    Carhart's notch and is a useful clinical marker for medial ossicular-chain fixation.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

CIC

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:

questions.text: On the day of delivery, a newborn baby is undergoing a screening test for hearing. Which of the following tests is likely to be performed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Otoacoustic emissions (OAE)
Ref: Read the text below    
Sol:
•    A newborn baby on the same day of delivery will undergo the Otoacoustic emissions (OAE) test as a screening test for hearing.
•    Universal Newborn Hearing Screening (UNHS) has become a standard practice in most developed countries. 
•    The identification of all newborns with hearing loss before 6 months has become an attainable and realistic goal. 
•    The goal is to screen newborn babies before 1 month of age, diagnose hearing loss before 3 months of age and start intervention as early as possible,or latest by 6 months of age.

questions.text: Which of the following is not canal wall down (CWD) mastoidectomy
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Combined approach tympanoplasty
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:  
Canal wall down (CWD) procedures
•    Modified radical mastoidectomy
•    Radical mastoidectomy
•    Atticotomy    
Canal wall up  (CWU) procedures
•    Cortical mastoidectomy ( schwartz operation)
•    Combined approach tympanoplasty

questions.text: A congenitally deaf child on radiological evaluation of cochlea and brain with MRI has been found to having absent cochlea. What is the best method of hearing rehabilitation in this case.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Auditory brain stem implant surgery
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:  
•    Brain stem implant is placed on lateral recess of 4th ventricle near cochlear nucleus for stimulation. 
•    The indications are- NF-2 cases with bilateral acoustic neuromas, congenital absence of VIII nerve, cochlear aplasia(Michel’s)

questions.text: 50 yr old female present with hard of hearing. On tuning fork test rinnes was negative on left side and positive on right side. Weber was lateralized toward on left. Absolute bone conduction test was reduced on right side. Comment on the most appropriate diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Right  sensorineural deafness.

Ref: Read the text below

questions.text: A 30 year old male is having Attic cholesteatoma of left ear with extradural abscess. Which of the following will be the operation of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Canal wall down mastoidectomy

Ref: Read the text below

Sol : 
•    Attic cholesteatoma is an indication for modified radical mastoidectomy. (Canal wall down mastoidectomy)

questions.text: Identify the incision shown the given image ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Wilde’s incision
Reference – Read the text below
Sol : 
•    Wilde's incision – This post-aural incision is used for a variant mastoiditis drainage, and was named after Sir William Wilde, an ENT surgeon in Dubli
•    Tympanomeatal flap is raised to expose the middle ear in endomeatal approach
•    Rosen’s incision is used in the endomeatal approach for stapedectomy
•    It is also used for exploratory tympanotomy.

questions.text: Given finding is highly suggestive of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Acoustic neuroma 
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:  
•    The configuration of the mass is of an ‘ice cream’ cone. 
•    Vestibular schwannoma is a benign tumor of glial cell origin.
•    It most commonly arises from the vestibular branch of the 8th cranial nerve.
•    It is a cause of unilateral sensorineural hearing loss in adults.
•    If bilateral, the patient most likely has neurofibromatosis Type 2.
•    Important other masses occurring at the CP angle, include epidermoid cyst, pseudo tumor, metastases and lymphoma.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic consults a physician because of severe and persistent earache. Otoscopic examination demonstrates foul-smelling purulent otorrhea and a red mass lesion of the external ear canal. Biopsy of the mass demonstrates granulation tissue rather than tumor. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pseudomonas aeruginosa 
Sol:

•    External otitis, or infection of the external ear canal, can be caused by a variety of organisms, notably including Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Proteus vulgaris, and Staphylococcus aureus. There is, however, a severe subtype of external otitis, malignant external otitis, of which you should be aware. This form is specifically caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and tends to affect elderly diabetics and AIDS patients, causing the findings illustrated in the question stem. It is particularly worrisome both because the Pseudomonas organism is so tissue destructive and because it is often highly resistant to most intravenous antibiotics. (Consult your local microbiology or pharmacology departments for advice about local sensitivities if you encounter the condition.) Complications can be devastating, including deafness, facial nerve paralysis, osteomyelitis, and meningitis. 
•    Escherichia coli can cause both external otitis and acute otitis media, but does not usually cause malignant external otitis. 
•    Haemophilus influenza is an important cause of acute otitis media. 
Proteus vulgaris can cause external otitis, but does not usually cause the malignant form.

Type B Curve

Laryngoceoele

•    Aquired laryngocele: Increased pressure in the laryngeal lumen wind instrument player)
•    Laryngopyocele: infected laryngocele

questions.text: Ostmann fat pads are associated with which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Eustachian tube
Ref: Read the text below    
Sol:
•    The Ostmann fat pads are masses of fatty tissues located inferolateral to the cartilaginous eustachian tubes.
•    It helps keep the tube closed, protecting it from the reflux of nasopharyngeal secretions and also prevents the transmission of nasopharyngeal pressure to the middle ear.

choices.text: Palatal Palsy, Temporo-parietal pain, Conductive Hearing Loss
Palatal Palsy, Temporo-parietal pain, Sensorineural Hearing Loss
Palatal Palsy, Retro-orbital pain, Conductive Hearing Loss

questions.text: Which of the following best describes Trotter's Triad
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Palatal Palsy, Temporo-parietal pain, Conductive Hearing Loss
Sol :  
•    Trotter’s triad is a unique symptom complex associated with infiltrative malignant tumours invading the lateral wall of nasopharynx or a lesion arising in the region of sinus of Morgagni.
•    Pathognomonic features in sequential order include ipsilateral conductive hearing loss due to eustachian tube block, trigeminal nerve neuralgia affecting the mandibular division initially and anaesthesia later, secondary to its invasion in foramen ovale, and palatal asymmetry owing to ipsilateral direct infiltration of levator palatini muscles.

questions.text: A child presents with history of foreign body ingestion.The X-ray picture is given in the image. What is the possible site of foreign body impaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Oesophagus

Sol :

questions.text: A child with throat pain and fever has been found to have whitish membrane in the Tonsillar region which bleeds on scrapping. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Diphtheric Tonsillitis

Sol :  

The whitish membrane extending beyond the tonsil, enlarges lymph nodes and bleed on removal go in favor of Diphtheria

questions.text: Which of the following vitamin deficiencies can cause laryngismus stridulus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Vitamin D
Ref: Read the text below    
Sol:
•    Laryngismus stridulus is primarily associated with a deficiency in vitamin D.
•    Laryngismus stridulus can be defined as laryngeal spasm caused by the sudden contraction of laryngeal muscles due to a reduced level of calcium. It is likely to be caused by vitamin D deficiency. 
•    Vitamin D, also known as cholecalciferol, plays a significant role in calcium and phosphate levels homeostasis. 
•    Its active form, calcitriol or 1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol is produced by sequential hydroxylation in the liver and kidneys. 
•    It primarily increases the serum calcium and phosphate levels. 
•    Deficiency of vitamin D leads to rickets.

questions.text: 4 yr old child with suspected FB non examination Palpatory thud and audible snap were seen. Comment on the site of FB
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Tracheal foreign body
Sol:                
•    A foreign body in trachea may move up and down the trachea between the carnia and the undersurface of vocal cords causing "audible slap" and "palpatory thud'.
Symptoms and signs of foreign bodies at different levels

choices.text: Hearing loss should be more than 30 dB
Hearing loss should be seen on minimum 3 frequencies
Hearing loss should have occurred within 3 days
Bilateral Hearing loss should be there

questions.text: One of the following is not the criteria to label a hearing loss as Sudden SNHL
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Bilateral Hearing loss should be there
Reference: Read the text below
Sol:    
•    A commonly used criterion to qualify for the diagnosis of sudden SNHL is a sensorineural hearing loss of greater than 30 dB over 3 contiguous pure-tone frequencies occurring within 3 days' period. 
•    Usually it presents as unilateral loss of hearing; bilateral involvement is rare

questions.text: Upon endoscopy, the following structure is seen which is marked with arrow. Name this structure:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Fossa of rosenmuller

Sol :  

 


•    Eustachian tube opening present on the lateral wall of nasopharynx, situated 1.25 cm behind the posterior end of inferior turbinate.
•    An elevation known as Torus tubarius raised by the cartilage of the tube bound the tube above and behind.
•    Above and behind the tubal elevation is a recess called fossa of Rosenmüller.
•    Fossa of Rosenmüller is the commonest site for origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
•    From lower end of torus tubarius a ridge extends to the lateral pharyngeal wall and is called salpingopharyngeal fold. It is raised by corresponding muscle.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presented with recurrent sinusitis. Surgical intervention is advised for this patient. Which of the following is gold standard investigation before endoscopic surgery like functional endoscopic sinus surgery
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

CT scan

Sol :  

•    CT scan of sinuses will tell the extent of disease, predisposing structural abnormalities, amount of destruction of bony walls and any extension to orbit and cranial cavity.
•    Investigation of choice for diagnosis of sinusitis is also CT scan.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Acute Laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis

Sol:     
•    The Xray shows the Steeple sign seen in Acute Laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis (Croup) .It is 
•    The most common organism responsible for croup is Parainfluenza virus type 1

questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: A 14 year old boy presents with reddish nasal mass, profuse epistaxis & Proptosis. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Juvenile nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma
Sol :  

•    Angiofibroma is the most common benign tumour of nasopharynx seen in adolescent males. It originates from sphenopalatine foramen. 
•    It’s a highly vascular tumour. CECT scan shows Hollman Miller ( =Antral) sign. Surgery is treatment of choice. 
•    Pre-op embolisation will reduce blood loss. 
•    Pre-op Estrogen, Flutamide ( androgen antagonist) are helpful in reducing blood loss.
•    Debulking or biopsy of this tumour is never done as it is a highly vascular tumour.
•    Tumours confined to nasopharynx can be approached through Wilson’s transpalatal approach. But tumours extending to cheek would need trans- maxillary approach using weber fergusson incision.

choices.text: Kiesselbach’s plexus is supplied mainly by sphenopalatine artery.
It is present on lateral wall of nose
It is present in the posterior part of nasal cavity

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Little's area
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Keisselbach's plexus is suuplied mainly by sphenopalatine artery.
Sol :  

•    Keisselbach’s plexus is made by superior labial, greater palatine, sphenopalatine and anterior ethmoidal arteries.
•    It is present on anterior part of septum

questions.text: In the case of anterior ethmoidal neuralgia, where is the anterior ethmoidal nerve most commonly compressed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Middle meatus

Ref: Read the text below    
Sol:
•    The middle meatus is the most common site of compression of the anterior ethmoidal nerve causing neuralgia.
•    Anterior ethmoidal neuralgia, also known as Sluder’s neuralgia is caused when the anterior ethmoidal nerve, a branch of the nasociliary nerve (which is itself a branch of the ophthalmic nerve, CN V1), is compressed. 
•    The most common site of compression is at the middle meatus, where the nerve may be impinged by anatomical variations, inflammation, or other pathologies affecting the paranasal sinuses.

choices.text: Plan surgical treatment with functional endoscopic sinus surgery
Bed rest and avoiding strenuous activity

questions.text: A 33-year-old male met with a road traffic accident. There is persistent watery discharge mixed with blood from his nose for 3 days which cannot be sniffed back. Which of the following should not be done in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Plan surgical treatment with functional endoscopic sinus surgery
Ref: Read the text below    
Sol:
•    In the given scenario of a male presenting with watery nasal discharge mixed with blood that cannot be sniffed back following a road traffic accident is suggestive of CSF rhinorrhea. 
•    Surgical treatment with functional endoscopic sinus surgery should not be done in this patient.

questions.text: Study the given slide and comment where the given structure drains:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Sphenoethmoidal recess

Ref: Read the text below
Sol
                                                    Ethmoid Sinus
• Drainage: anterior cells drain into the ethmoid infundibulum, posterior cells drain into the spheno-
                                                MAXILLARY SINUS
1.    Drainage: ethmoid infundibulum (middle meatus, 10–30% have accessory ostium)

                                                       FRONTAL SINUS
•    frontal recess in anterior middle meatus either medial or lateral to the uncinate (posterior and medial to agar nasi cells), may also be lateral to agar nasi cells

The sphenoidal sinus drains into the sphenoethmoidal recess superior to the superior concha

questions.text: Enlarged orange tonsils as shown in image is found in :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

TANGIER DISEASE
Ref: Read the text below
Sol :    
•    In tangier disease there is a DEFECT IN EFFLUX OF CELLULAR CHOLESTEROL, leading to cholesterol accumulation in reticuloendothelial cells.
•    ENLARGE ORANGE TONSILS are pathognomonic of tangier disease.

choices.text: It is benign but has malignant potential
It is malignant and do not metastasize

questions.text: True about inverted papilloma arising from lateral wall of nose:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

It is benign but has malignant potential
Sol :  

•    Inverted papilloma, which arises from the mucosa of lateral wall of nose, most frequently affects males in the age group of 30-5O years. 
•    It is benign but has malignant potential
•    Only 10-15% are associated with malignancy. 
•    Treatment is complete excision which amounts to medial maxillectomy. 
•    Post-operative radiotherapy is not necessary.

choices.text: Shift patient to OT and ligation bleeding vessel
Shift patient to OT and cautery.
Use hemostatic agents do 3 to 4 gargles per day

questions.text: A Child underwent tonsillectomy and after surgery shifted to recovery room where he started bleeding and on examination a clot was seen at the site of surgery. Next step in management will be ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Shift patient to OT and ligation bleeding vessel
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
Primary haemorrhage. 
•    Occurs at the time of operation.
•    It can be controlled by pressure, ligation or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.

Reactionary haemorrhage. 
•    Occurs within a period of 24 h and can be controlled by simple measures such as removal of the clot, application of pressure or vasoconstrictor.
•    Presence of a clot prevents the clipping action of the superior constrictor muscle on the vessels which pass through it (compare postpartum uterine bleeding).
Secondary haemorrhage. 
•    Usually seen between the fifth to tenth postoperative day. 
•    It is the result of sepsis and premature separation of the membrane.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presented with complaints of a foreign body sensation in nose and frequent spitting of blood-tinged saliva for 6 months duration. On examination, a reddish pedunculated mass studded with whitish spots was seen hanging in nasal cavity. The patient also gave history of taking frequent baths in local ponds. After a clinical diagnosis of rhinosporidiosis, he underwent complete excision of the mass after bipolar cauterisation of the base under local anaesthesis.Postoperative histopathology revealed multiple sporangia in various stages of maturation with dense inflammation.Choose the most appropriate diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Rhinosporodiosis
Ref: Read the text below.
Sol:-
Rhinosporidiosis:
Organism: Rhinosporidium seeberi. Distribution: India (Southern parts), Sri lanka.
Sites of Affection:
Most commonly: Nose and Nasopharynx Mulberry shaped polypoidal mass studded with white dots or sporangia on its under surface.
Site: Vestibule (septal area).
Treatment:
Complete excision of the mass with a cutting diathermy and cauterization of its base.
Medical management: Local injection of corticosteroids and courses of dapsone and amphotericin.
